results.title: TERROR NULLIUS
results.brief_description: Equal parts political satire, eco-horror and road movie, TERROR NULLIUS is a rogue remapping of national mythology, where a misogynistic remark is met with the sharp beak of a bird, feminist bike gangs rampage and bicentenary celebrations are ravaged by flesh-eating sheep.

constellations_other.name: Joy of drag
constellations_other.description: The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert is a groundbreaking Australian film with a small budget and big impact that's taken queer Australian stories to the world.

constellations_other.name: Copy, transform and combine
constellations_other.description: You will see me (2020) repurposes material sourced from the history of the moving image – archival footage, news, interviews, documentaries, reality TV, video diaries and social media – to reflect on the way we perform in front of and reveal ourselves to the camera.

constellations_other.name: Remix and resistance (Since I left you)
constellations_other.description: The Avalanches' music videos are part of a long artistic tradition of reappropriation as a means of reframing perception.

constellations_other.name: Great southern land?
constellations_other.description: Australia is often mythologised in film and TV, but national myths must not only be embraced, but resisted.

results.description:
Hitch a ride into the dark heart of Australia with Soda_Jerk’s TERROR NULLIUS, a blistering, badly behaved sample-based film that confronts the horror of our contemporary moment.

Equal parts political satire, eco-horror and road movie, TERROR NULLIUS is a rogue remapping of national mythology, where a misogynistic remark is met with the sharp beak of a bird, feminist bike gangs rampage and bicentenary celebrations are ravaged by flesh-eating sheep.

By intricately remixing fragments of Australia’s pop culture and film legacy, TERROR NULLIUS interrogates the unstable entanglement of fiction that underpins this country’s vexed sense of self.

Following the success of The Was, their 2016 collaboration with The Avalanches, Soda_Jerk return with a work that’s dark, hopeful, irreverent and urgent.
description_for_label:
Hitch a ride into the dark heart of Australia with Soda_Jerk’s TERROR NULLIUS, a blistering, badly behaved sample-based film that confronts the horror of our contemporary moment.

By intricately remixing fragments of Australia’s pop culture and film legacy, TERROR NULLIUS interrogates the unstable entanglement of fiction that underpins this country’s vexed sense of self.

Following the success of The Was, their 2016 collaboration with The Avalanches, Soda_Jerk return with a work that’s dark, hopeful, irreverent and urgent.

results.title: The Beehive
results.credit_line:
Zanny Begg

Digital video, stereo sound, variable duration

Artbank + ACMI Commission, ACMI Collection
results.material_description: Single channel digital video and software, colour and audio
results.brief_description: The Beehive explores the unsolved murder of Sydney anti-development campaigner Juanita Nielsen. The inaugural Artbank + ACMI Commission, the video installation examines themes of gentrification, corruption, sex-work, feminism and non-conformist lifestyles.

constellations_other.name: Neo-Noir
constellations_other.description: Blade Runner's retro-futurist setting lends it a timeless quality, while also connecting it to the past and the future.

constellations_other.name: Women and crime
constellations_other.description: The allure and fascination of dangerous women and women in danger.

results.description:
Zanny Begg’s The Beehive is the inaugural Artbank + ACMI Commission supporting ambitious and experimental screen-based work at the nexus of film and art.

The Beehive is a non-linear experimental documentary exploring the unsolved murder of Sydney anti-development campaigner and glamourous style icon Juanita Nielsen in Kings Cross in 1975. Juanita’s body has never been found and her murderers have never been charged.

The Beehive consists of scripted fictions, documentary interviews and choreographed scenes with multiple actors playing the role of Juanita. The film is ever-changing, as a different combination of footage is randomly selected for each screening with 1,344 possible variations. The Beehive therefore continually morphs and evolves to reveal different interpretations of this violent historical act and its social context. Operating like a forensic investigation, the film presents a variety of puzzle pieces, asking new questions and potentially pointing to an answer.

The title is a reference to Juanita Nielsen’s famous hairdo but is also a metaphor for human cities. In classical times the beehive was seen as a hierarchical and densely industrious hub; in pre-Christian symbolism the beehive was a dark cooperative womb guided by a powerful queen. This clash between utilitarian and feminist interpretations of our cities provides a poetic tension that flows through the film.

Who killed Juanita Nielsen?
description_for_label: The Beehive explores the unsolved murder of Sydney anti-development campaigner Juanita Nielsen. The inaugural Artbank + ACMI Commission, the video installation examines themes of gentrification, corruption, sex-work, feminism and non-conformist lifestyles.
results.credit_line_for_label:
Zanny Begg

Digital video, stereo sound, variable duration

Artbank + ACMI Commission, ACMI Collection

results.title: Alt-Right Arabesque
results.credit_line:
Baiden Pailthorpe
Single-channel video, 3 mins.
ACMI Collection
results.brief_description:
Alt-Right Arabesque continues Pailthorpe’s interest in the performing digital body, yet with a new focus on the aesthetics of the resurgent and re-branded fascism (the so-called Alt-right). The sickly-looking protagonist in this work symbolises the infamous 4chan moderator or frequent Reddit user, who spectacularly twirls en arabesque in box-fresh Nike Airmax. A variety of surreal political imagery, visual references and cinematic techniques long associated with fascism and propaganda in the history of cinema are combined in this animation to create a strange and intense response to the overwhelming weirdness of 2016.
[Source: https://sydneycontemporary.com.au/video17/
Last accessed 2/9/2020]

results.title: [Nixon Family Home Movies: Reel 3]
results.brief_description:
In the Nixon Family Home Movie Collection, married film enthusiasts Les and Dorothy Nixon have captured their family life from when their children are very young to when they are young adults, at home in Geelong, during wonderful beach holidays at Point Roadknight on the Victorian coast, and when going about their everyday activities, from the 1960s to the 1980s.

The films show life in regional and suburban Victoria at the time: playing in the backyard and bike riding down the street (no helmets of course), lots of tennis, lots of beach and swimming, lots of family visits, birthday parties and family barbeques or picnic gatherings. Along the way, the films also record the distinctive fashion (often handmade) and hairstyles of the 1960s, 1970s and 1980s, through Dorothy Nixon being so stylish a dresser herself, and at the many family weddings across the extended family.

The films are made on Standard 8mm and then Super 8mm film, and are in reasonable condition though a little shaky or damaged at times.

This film is a wonderful composite of the Nixon family’s life enjoying the company of their extended family at weddings, birthday gatherings and at the family holiday homes as well as on their travels to the Gold Coast, Queensland and Eildon Weir, Victoria. We see Karen turn six in the film as well as a great Christmas scene when both children are particularly excited to receive their presents, a watch for Karen and a scooter for Stuart.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:10:00 children on the beach at Portarlington
00:00:52:00 at a zoo
00:02:40:00 wedding with a tall headdress for the bride and bridesmaids in dark pink 1960s style dresses
00:04:10:00 Karen’s first day at school, in her uniform with school bag
00:04:24:00 Stuart on a trike (tricycle) saluting the camera
00:04:40:00 picnic on the beach with lots of extended family members
00:05:00:00 treasure hunt in the sand
00:06:54:00 the children on a farm tractor
00:07:20:00 the cousins of the family in a row at a driveway gate
00:08:19:00 Les, Karen and Stuart walking out of the water at the beach
00:09:49:00 children amusement park on ‘dodgem’ cars
00:11:26:00 Karen and Stuart being rowed in a rowboat, followed by a speedboat rushing past, very close to the shore
00:12:00:00 view of waterfront houses at the Gold Coast
00:12:10:00 TAA airplane taking off at an airport
00:13:27:00 extended family wedding with bridesmaids in what would have been (at the time) a very fashionable and wonderful burnt orange
00:15:28:00 Stuart receiving his Christmas scooter
00:16:00:00 Dorothy and daughter Karen in matching outfits
00:16:25:00 family members gathered under some shady trees at the beach
00:16:47:00 Karen very confidently ‘dinking’ her younger brother Stuart on his new scooter (by giving him a ride)
00:19:27:00 Dorothy and other women in the family laugh as they climb up, and fall on, a steep sand dune
00:20:13:00 Dorothy, Karen and Stuart stand outside their caravan at the beach
00:20:19:00 a family wedding, bridesmaids in purple and sporting some great examples of 1960s hairstyles
00:21:43:00 Karen’s sixth birthday party
00:22:27:00 Karen backstroking through the water
00:23:17:00 family picnic including a woman wearing a wonderful paisley shirt typical of fashion at the time
00:24:40:00 cooking on a vintage three-legged barbeque
00:26:00:00 a birthday party held at a holiday home possibly at Point Roadknight

results.title: [Ted Parsons Home Movies: Reel 4]
results.brief_description:
Ted Parsons was a keen amateur filmmaker of the 1940s to 1960s. Ted’s films feature life in and around the Victorian regional city of Wangaratta post-war. This was a period of prosperity and optimism largely due to a successful textile industry that took Wangaratta from a small country town to major rural city, declared in 1959.

Ted captures the many sporting and social events, venues and clubs, holidays and travel along with scenes of everyday life. The collection also shows the broader issues faced by country people such as the regular flooding events around the Ovens and King Rivers.

Wangaratta’s success story as a manufacturing town traces the path of post-war migration and the accompanying growth of Australia’s economy, which makes these films particularly interesting.

The Ted Parsons Home Movie Collection has been donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s grandson Barry Parsons. The films have been made on 16mm film.

In this film, Ted captures a trip to Queensland and New South Wales. The film features scenes of holidaying in Queensland, touring around Surfers Paradise, Brisbane, the Sunshine Coast and Coffs Harbour, before travelling down the East Coast from Sydney to Eden and Lakes Entrance. The film includes memorable scenes such as a show of aqua ballet and water ski stunts in Surfers Paradise, dolphins in the Pet Porpoise Pool in Coffs Harbour, historic buildings in Brisbane and fruit farms on the Sunshine Coast.

Of particular interest is Lennon’s Hotel in Broadbeach, which was one of the earliest hotels in Surfers Paradise. At the time, there were few buildings around and the hotel was surrounded by stretches of sand dunes and unsealed roads. It would become the site of the current ‘Oasis Shopping Centre’.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:04:00 title ‘Queensland Gold Coast 1961’ followed by a sequence where travel brochures are tossed over the title card for hotels and destinations including Brampton Island and Surfers Paradise
00:00:23:00 looking toward Lennon’s Hotel, a very colourful, modern 1960s style roadside hotel
00:00:50:00 sign ‘Welcome to Surfers Paradise’
00:00:55:00 scenes around the pool at the hotel including women sunbaking in bikinis
00:01:32:00 sign ‘KR Darling Downs Bacon’ above a shopping plaza
00:02:37:00 the bridge to Chevron Island in Queensland
00:02:54:00 sign in dry grassland for ‘Shopping Centre Here’
00:03:24:00 handpainted sign for ‘Water Ski Revue and Aqua Ballet’ in Surfers Paradise Gardens
00:03:48:00 scenes of spectators on grassy slopes and the performers on the waterskiing show
00:04:41:00 a woman with a full head of hair ‘curlers’ which was a not uncommon look in the 1960s
00:04:51:00 a woman in costume for the aqua ballet, wearing a blue feathered tutu
00:05:04:00 various waterskiing stunts entertain the appreciative crowd
00:06:22:00 Mount Coot-Tha in Brisbane, a mountain with panoramic views over the city
00:08:14:00 traffic on a main road lined with palm trees
00:09:38:00 view of Brisbane City Hall
00:10:00:00 view of the Queensland National Art Gallery in its former premises on Gregory Terrace where it operated from 1931 to 1974
00:10:25:00 sign for the ‘Lone Pine Koala Sanctuary estd. 1927’
00:10:37:00 a koala riding on the back of a German Shepherd dog, hugging its neck
00:11:35:00 view of the grand sandstone Forgan Smith Building at the University of Queensland
00:13:26:00 exterior of the Buderim Ginger Growers Co-Op’s original ‘Merrybud’ factory, west of Mooloolaba on the Sunshine Coast
00:13:48:00 fruit farms, including strawberry fields and pineapple groves
00:17:00:00 fruit pickers and workers in the cane fields
00:20:11:00 kite surfer on the river
00:20:57:00 bougainvillea and two women in the gardens
00:22:00:00 banana plants
00:22:37:00 title card ‘Caloundra’
00:22:45:00 exterior of the Reef Hotel
00:23:34:00 large ship arriving on the coast
00:24:02:00 title card ‘Coolangatta’
00:24:05:00 exterior of the Kirra Beach Hotel
00:24:39:00 the Natureland Zoological Gardens
00:28:38:00 swimming and snorkelling with 1950s examples of oxygen tanks
00:29:37:00 exterior view of the George Gilltrap’s Auto Museum with displays of early twentieth century cars and trucks
00:30:48:00 a demonstration of a 1913 fire engine with a group of firemen dressed in uniform, watched by a crowd of onlookers
00:31:50:00 men pumping the fire hose
00:33:40:00 the Pet Porpoise Pool in Coffs Harbour, a small aquarium
00:35:07:00 visitors feeding dolphins, leaping up to catch fish from people’s hands
00:37:29:00 sign for ‘Galapagos Island Giant Tortoise’ named Harry
00:38:47:00 sign for ‘The Sanctuary’ across a river
00:38:53:00 rosellas feeding
00:39:16:00 two women feeding rosellas from bowls, birds landing on their heads and arms
00:39:36:00 a toddler screaming as a kangaroo paws its head
00:40:32:00 the Terranora Lakes Country Club Estate with golf course and swimming pool
00:41:30:00 the Hornibrook Bridge, a heritage-listed bridge built by Manuel Hornibrook in the early 1930s crossing Bramble Bay
00:42:39:00 the Sydney Harbour Bridge
00:42:52:00 Macquarie Lightstation, Vaucluse, which was Australia’s first lighthouse
00:44:27:00 focused views of the Sydney Harbour Bridge, followed by views across the harbour
00:46:09:00 title card reads ‘Eden’
00:46:21:00 a campfire on the beach with a billy boiling
00:47:05:00 title card ‘Lakes Entrance’ followed by views over the estuary
00:47:51:00 fisherman pulling fish from a net on a dinghy
00:48:55:00 roadside picnic with table set up and playpen for a toddler
00:49:58:00 cooking sausages and bacon over stones
00:50:30:00 title card ‘The End’

00:41:30:00 the Hornibrook Bridge, a heritage-listed bridge built by Manuel Hornibrook in the early 1930s crossing Bramble Bay
00:42:39:00 the Sydney Harbour Bridge
00:42:52:00 Macquarie Lightstation, Vaucluse, which was Australia’s first lighthouse
00:44:27:00 focused views of the Sydney Harbour Bridge, followed by views across the harbour
00:46:09:00 title card reads ‘Eden’
00:46:21:00 a campfire on the beach with a billy boiling
00:47:05:00 title card ‘Lakes Entrance’ followed by views over the estuary
00:47:51:00 fisherman pulling fish from a net on a dinghy
00:48:55:00 roadside picnic with table set up and playpen for a toddler
00:49:58:00 cooking sausages and bacon over stones
00:50:30:00 title card ‘The End’
description_for_label:
Ted Parsons was a keen amateur filmmaker of the 1940s to 1960s. Ted’s films feature life in and around the Victorian regional city of Wangaratta post-war. This was a period of prosperity and optimism largely due to a successful textile industry that took Wangaratta from a small country town to major rural city, declared in 1959.

Ted captures the many sporting and social events, venues and clubs, holidays and travel along with scenes of everyday life. The collection also shows the broader issues faced by country people such as the regular flooding events around the Ovens and King Rivers.

Wangaratta’s success story as a manufacturing town traces the path of post-war migration and the accompanying growth of Australia’s economy, which makes these films particularly interesting.

The Ted Parsons Home Movie Collection has been donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s grandson Barry Parsons. The films have been made on 16mm film.

In this film, Ted captures a trip to Queensland and New South Wales. The film features scenes of holidaying in Queensland, touring around Surfers Paradise, Brisbane, the Sunshine Coast and Coffs Harbour, before travelling down the East Coast from Sydney to Eden and Lakes Entrance. The film includes memorable scenes such as a show of aqua ballet and water ski stunts in Surfers Paradise, dolphins in the Pet Porpoise Pool in Coffs Harbour, historic buildings in Brisbane and fruit farms on the Sunshine Coast.

Of particular interest is Lennon’s Hotel in Broadbeach, which was one of the earliest hotels in Surfers Paradise. At the time, there were few buildings around and the hotel was surrounded by stretches of sand dunes and unsealed roads. It would become the site of the current ‘Oasis Shopping Centre’.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:04:00 title ‘Queensland Gold Coast 1961’ followed by a sequence where travel brochures are tossed over the title card for hotels and destinations including Brampton Island and Surfers Paradise
00:00:23:00 looking toward Lennon’s Hotel, a very colourful, modern 1960s style roadside hotel
00:00:50:00 sign ‘Welcome to Surfers Paradise’
00:00:55:00 scenes around the pool at the hotel including women sunbaking in bikinis
00:01:32:00 sign ‘KR Darling Downs Bacon’ above a shopping plaza
00:02:37:00 the bridge to Chevron Island in Queensland
00:02:54:00 sign in dry grassland for ‘Shopping Centre Here’
00:03:24:00 handpainted sign for ‘Water Ski Revue and Aqua Ballet’ in Surfers Paradise Gardens
00:03:48:00 scenes of spectators on grassy slopes and the performers on the waterskiing show
00:04:41:00 a woman with a full head of hair ‘curlers’ which was a not uncommon look in the 1960s
00:04:51:00 a woman in costume for the aqua ballet, wearing a blue feathered tutu
00:05:04:00 various waterskiing stunts entertain the appreciative crowd
00:06:22:00 Mount Coot-Tha in Brisbane, a mountain with panoramic views over the city
00:08:14:00 traffic on a main road lined with palm trees
00:09:38:00 view of Brisbane City Hall
00:10:00:00 view of the Queensland National Art Gallery in its former premises on Gregory Terrace where it operated from 1931 to 1974
00:10:25:00 sign for the ‘Lone Pine Koala Sanctuary estd. 1927’
00:10:37:00 a koala riding on the back of a German Shepherd dog, hugging its neck
00:11:35:00 view of the grand sandstone Forgan Smith Building at the University of Queensland
00:13:26:00 exterior of the Buderim Ginger Growers Co-Op’s original ‘Merrybud’ factory, west of Mooloolaba on the Sunshine Coast
00:13:48:00 fruit farms, including strawberry fields and pineapple groves
00:17:00:00 fruit pickers and workers in the cane fields
00:20:11:00 kite surfer on the river
00:20:57:00 bougainvillea and two women in the gardens
00:22:00:00 banana plants
00:22:37:00 title card ‘Caloundra’
00:22:45:00 exterior of the Reef Hotel
00:23:34:00 large ship arriving on the coast
00:24:02:00 title card ‘Coolangatta’
00:24:05:00 exterior of the Kirra Beach Hotel
00:24:39:00 the Natureland Zoological Gardens
00:28:38:00 swimming and snorkelling with 1950s examples of oxygen tanks
00:29:37:00 exterior view of the George Gilltrap’s Auto Museum with displays of early twentieth century cars and trucks
00:30:48:00 a demonstration of a 1913 fire engine with a group of firemen dressed in uniform, watched by a crowd of onlookers
00:31:50:00 men pumping the fire hose
00:33:40:00 the Pet Porpoise Pool in Coffs Harbour, a small aquarium
00:35:07:00 visitors feeding dolphins, leaping up to catch fish from people’s hands
00:37:29:00 sign for ‘Galapagos Island Giant Tortoise’ named Harry
00:38:47:00 sign for ‘The Sanctuary’ across a river
00:38:53:00 rosellas feeding
00:39:16:00 two women feeding rosellas from bowls, birds landing on their heads and arms
00:39:36:00 a toddler screaming as a kangaroo paws its head
00:40:32:00 the Terranora Lakes Country Club Estate with golf course and swimming pool
00:41:30:00 the Hornibrook Bridge, a heritage-listed bridge built by Manuel Hornibrook in the early 1930s crossing Bramble Bay
00:42:39:00 the Sydney Harbour Bridge
00:42:52:00 Macquarie Lightstation, Vaucluse, which was Australia’s first lighthouse
00:44:27:00 focused views of the Sydney Harbour Bridge, followed by views across the harbour
00:46:09:00 title card reads ‘Eden’
00:46:21:00 a campfire on the beach with a billy boiling
00:47:05:00 title card ‘Lakes Entrance’ followed by views over the estuary
00:47:51:00 fisherman pulling fish from a net on a dinghy
00:48:55:00 roadside picnic with table set up and playpen for a toddler
00:49:58:00 cooking sausages and bacon over stones
00:50:30:00 title card ‘The End’

results.title: [Nicoll Family Home Movies: Reel 3]
results.brief_description:
Filmmaker Alexander Nicoll made a range of home movies in Australia from the 1930s to the 1960s. The family film collection was donated to ACMI by Alexendar’s son Mac.

This reel features the family at Carrum beach in Victoria. We see some great examples of swimsuits at the time as well as women’s suits and hats and a boy in a kilt. The reel ends with scenes around the Shrine of Remembrance in Melbourne.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 begins with two women and a boy walking through sandy bush to the beach, smiling at the camera
00:00:36:00 father and son atop an upturned boat on the beach, posing and waving for the camera
00:00:35:00 the boy running along the sand toward the camera
00:00:45:00 woman running from a bathing box along the sand, stopping briefly for the camera where we see her wearing a knotted headscarf, typical of the day, as a bathing cap
00:01:30:00 man drying himself post swim
00:01:35:00 example of a halter neck one piece women’s swimwear of the era
00:01:57:00 scenes of bushland before we see people picking blackberries
00:02:40:00 a child stares at the camera
00:02:45:00 two older women wearing suits and felt hats typical of the era, sitting on a car running board, one knitting
00:03:00:00 the family group are playing for the camera before playing in a park
00:03:35:00 group picnic around the cars so the running boards can be used as seats
00:04:40:00 riverside stroll with terrier dog
00:05:07:00 backyard cricket practice
00:06:00:00 young boy in kilt and cap with mother in stylish suit and shoes of the day
00:06:11:00 scenes around the Shrine of Remembrance in Melbourne

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 9]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film shows scenes from around the Northern Territory as Wallace and companions travel by car, with what appears to be camping gear packed on the roof, to Kulera, Finke River and Tempe Downs. As always, Wallace films the various landscapes as he travels.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 road sign ‘Kulgera 168’ followed by views of the long dusty red road ahead from the moving car and a handmade sign for ‘Goody Lookout’
00:00:30:00 sign ‘Finke River’, the river and a low bridge which the travellers’ car crosses
00:01:05:00 metalwork sign for ‘NTRB Henbury Meteorites Reserve’ followed by driving scenes through dusty scrub
00:03:14:00 a hopping kangaroo and a Northern Territory magpie goose walks through long grasses
00:03:35:00 old cattleyards
00:03:45:00 Kings Canyon and many views of surrounding countryside
00:09:46:00 a golden full moon at night

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 8]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film captures a trip by car to the Victorian town of Beechworth and surrounds.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:10:00 title card ‘WHC presents’ and ‘Historic Beechworth’ followed by the town welcome sign and some very quiet streets
00:00:47:00 ‘Beechworth Post Office’
00:01:24:00 looking down into an historic street of buildings with original verandas as well as an ‘Esso’ sign in the foreground and ‘Mobil’ further along
00:01:32:00 ‘Burke Memorial in stained glass (for ‘Robert O’Hara Bourke’) followed by a very old cottage and many other historic buildings
00:05:12:00 sign for ‘The Ovens Goldfields Hospital’ includes highlights of the hospital’s history such as being the only hospital between Melbourne and Goulburn
00:05:57:00 bushwalkers, followed by a small aircraft dropping fertilizer and views of the countryside
00:06:30:00 views of the ‘Beechworth Powder Magazine’ building and plaque for the opening by ‘the Honourable RJ Hamer’ in 1966
00:08:05:00 views of a ‘bush hut’ among scrub and trees and another small cottage which could be the home of ‘bushranger’ Ned Kelly
00:08:50:00 country views, a creek and waterfall, and a lake or river with speed boats
00:10:15:00 views around an old cemetery including a sign for ‘Chinese Ceremonial Burning Towers’ before seeing the towers and some graves with Chinese lettering on the headstones
00:11:35:00 travelling a dusty road by car through the bush, past a lovely ageing house with very deep veranda until the sign ‘Mt Pilot Scenic Reserve’
00:12:36:00 farmland and old farmhouses, some views of flora and fauna and a lookout tower and mountain views
00:13:07:00 a large lizard on a rock
00:13:28:00 lookout tower
00:13:44:00 photographers on a summit
00:14:16:00 title card ‘The End’

This film captures a group trip by tourist bus, four wheel drive vehicles and truck around the ‘Gulf Country’. The Gulf Country is the region of woodland and savanna grassland surrounding the Gulf of Carpentaria in north western Queensland and parts of the Northern Territory, Australia.

We see many dirt roads and sandy tracks so that we see both a tourist bus and four wheel drive vehicles being dug out of the sand. As always, Wallace includes close-ups of any flora and fauna that catch
his eye along the way.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 titles ‘A Walkabout Film’, ‘Gulf Country’, ‘A WHC Film’
00:01:15:00 sign for ‘Four Wheel Drive’.
00:01:21:00 a large lorry style truck travelling ahead on dirt road.
00:01:31:00 digging a vehicle out of sand on a track.
00:02:30:00 tourist bus being hauled from the sandy track by a truck.
00:03:42:00 particularly colourful bird in a tree.
00:03:57:00 people in a small boat catching fish.
00:04:55:00 a row of tents for camping lined up along a riverbank.
00:07:45:00 close up of a blackened ‘billy can’ set over a fire and then a wider shot of a group of picnic-goers.
00:08:09:00 a woman in an example of a 1970s style ‘halter-neck’ top.
00:08:32:00 animal footprints in the dust followed by a large snake making progress through the grass
00:09:14:00 large truck and bus with baggage loaded on roof travel down a dusty road
00:09:57:00 cattle in stockyards
00:10:27:00 wetlands and wildflowers
00:11:45:00 swimming in a river
00:11:53:00 a close-up of a spider in the middle of a large web wit the blue of the river in the background
00:12:53:00 title card ‘The End’
results.description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

his eye along the way.
